case_vignette: A 26-year-old woman presents to the medicine clinic with swelling around the right side of her chin and neck (Image A). She reports pain when moving her jaw and chewing. Her symptoms developed two days after receiving an uncomplicated tonsillectomy. She has been followed by a general medical physician since birth and has received all of her standard health maintenance procedures. Vital signs are stable with the exception of a temperature of 38.4 degrees Celcius. The area in question on the right side is exquisitely tender. The remainder of his exam is benign.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, it's possible that you may have developed a post-tonsillectomy infection or abscess.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, it's possible that you may have developed an abscess or a collection of pus in the tissue near your tonsils. This can be caused by a bacterial infection that can occur after a tonsillectomy.

I would recommend that you seek medical attention immediately to have this evaluated by a healthcare professional. They may perform a physical examination, take a medical history, and possibly order imaging studies such as a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis.

In the meantime, you can try applying a warm compress to the affected area to help reduce the pain and swelling. You can also take over-the-counter pain medication such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to help manage your discomfort.
